subject: Abort disconnect if invalid udid
commit_message:
Abort disconnect if invalid udid

The vSCSI physical volume may hit an issue if there is an hdisk without
a UDID.  The connect flow handles this and will not map.  Which then
causes a revert.  However, during the revert the code tries to remove
the hdisk.  This causes a significant issue.

This change set detects this path by adding a flag to check if udid is
None.  If so, it presents a warning message to the operator.  It then
allows the revert flow to continue properly.

subject: Fix issue when stop/wait order is not respected
commit_message:
Fix issue when stop/wait order is not respected

If stop/wait order is not respected, the following occurs:
* wait take the sever lock, and wait executor to finish
* then stop is called, try to get the lock to stop the executor
  but it can't because wait is waiting with the lock acquired

This change fixes that, and also removes the restriction
to call stop before wait. The lock and the _running flag
ensure that everything is called with the good order.

Change-Id: I9317928fd92c90cac9723dd6772348fbdbce33cf

subject: libvirt: use log file and serial console at the same time
commit_message:
libvirt: use log file and serial console at the same time

The config option "[serial_console].enabled" is used as a switch by
the libvirt driver to determine if EITHER the instance log file OR
the serial console should be created as a device for the guest.
Over the last months I was not able to get an answer why this design
was chosen. Frankly, I believe that it is a bug. Because I couldn't
find any "prove" that the current implementation is "wrong", I have
chosen the "blueprint way" to commit this change.

To be precise: If cloud admins set the compute node config option
"[serial_console].enabled" to "True", they prevent that the REST API
for the "os-getConsoleOutput" action for guests on these compute nodes
will return anything (because nothing gets logged). End users, who call
that REST API, will sometimes get a result and sometimes not, depending
on the configuration of the host where the instance gets scheduled to.

This patch set will allow the creation of BOTH devices (log file AND
serial console) for the guest. Which means that the REST API action
"os-getConsoleOutput" will return a result, even if the "serial console"
feature was enabled or not.

UpgradeImpact:
Instances, which get launched on compute nodes which have this patch,
will have 2 devices ("tcp" AND "file") instead of the 1 device
("tcp" OR "file") they get without this patch. Existing instances
which get migrated to a patched host, won't get the additional device
unless they get rebuild. Guests which were already built with multiple
serial devices (through flavor extra specs or image metadata) could
exceed the upper limit of 4 serial devices after a rebuild. Due to
bug 1425640, which says that the REST API only returns the very first
serial console device, I believe that this is not yet really exploited
by customers.

Implements: blueprint libvirt-log-file-and-serial-console

Change-Id: Ic6fbc2402daf28f4db4117be1c7ae7bc3d1a8e9b

subject: Properly detect backing instance is gone
commit_message:
Properly detect backing instance is gone

The instance_manager's current caching of instance_info only happens
once and is never refreshed.  This causes update_state() to not notice
a backing instance is gone until it fails a API liveliness check.

This fixes it by updating the instance_info on every run of ensure_cache(),
in the same way it does for the router_obj.  This will properly detect
a backing instance is gone and rebuild the router without the slow
failing liveliness check.

Fixing this introduces a race where we try to check the API server of
a booted instance that does not yet have ports associated.  This also
fixes this by considering instances with no management port to still
be in the booting state.

The common practice of making nova-compute (with vmwareapi driver
chosen) HA is to have it run in active/passive mode controlled by
Pacemaker.  In that case Pacemaker can move nova-compute instance to
another host, should something happen to the original one, which
effectively will cause change of the IP address - thus, all cached
images will have to be re-downloaded again, despite the fact they are
still there in the datastore and still belong to this particular
nova-compute instance.

I02e758af19cf3a652a5c39d02904e73a1088fe60 made it possible to use the
`cache_prefix' config option to denote, which cache directory should
be used by a particular nova-compute instance. As long as we set the
same `cache_prefix' value for all nova-compute processes running in
active/passive mode, the cache directory will be the same on every
host.

subject: Break apart and document the upgrade process
commit_message:
Break apart and document the upgrade process

This change breaks up the Juno>Kilo upgrade script such that its now
available to be called as separate pieces. This change allows the
deployer to call the various parts of the upgrade script as needed.
Special care has been taken to make the BASH parts of the script as
idempotent as possible

Documentation has been added to cover all of the scripts, what they
do, how they do it, and when to call them. While the `run-upgrade.sh`
script is the main entry point to doing an online upgrade, the script
itself is now simply an orchestrator which can be followed or
customized as needed.

The documentation should cover most, if not all, of the aspects of
an RPC Juno > OpenStack-Ansible Kilo upgrade. The deployer will
also have information on what we consider best practice and should
have the information required to make a decision on realistic
deliverables while migrating an old deployment to the new community
format which includes upgrading the installed OpenStack release as
well.

A play was added `swift-repo-adjustments.yml` to verify all hosts
have access to the ubuntu backports repositories as they're
required both in and outside of a container.

A restart was added to the swift rsyncd service restart handler
because the rsyncd service configs have shifted around and in some
cases its necessary for the service to be stopped and started more
than once to clean up old pid files.

subject: FastWatchedFileHandler class was added
commit_message:
FastWatchedFileHandler class was added

If one program opens file(in our case log file) and this file is moved
or removed by other program, the first program still works with opened
file descriptor.
If we use WatchedFileHandler it allows to recreate file only after
first emitting of WatchedFileHandler. It means that deleted files still
consumes disk space.
Class FastWatchedFileHandler is designed to observe file system. If log
file is moved or removed FastWatchedFileHandler instantaneously closes
old file descriptor and creates new file with specified name.
Config option watch-log-file was added. If this option is set
FastWatchedFileHandler handler will be used.
Option watch-log-file brings effect for Linux platform only.

subject: Implementation of keepalived for haproxy
commit_message:
Implementation of keepalived for haproxy

This commit uses a keepalived role, available in
ansible galaxy, to configure keepalived for haproxy

Keepalived makes the haproxy truely HA, by having
haproxy's VIP highly available between the hosts
defined in the inventory.

The keepalived role configuration is fully
documented on the upstream role.

To configure keepalived on your host, you only have to
give it a variable (dict). A template handles the
generation of the configuration of keepalived.

By default, the variable files defined in vars/configs/
are enough to have a keepalived working for haproxy,
with a master-backup configuration.

You can define other variable files by setting
haproxy_keepalived_(master|backup)_vars in your
user_variables. This should point to a "variable
template" file like the one you can find
in vars/configs/*

The haproxy playbook has been changed to rely on
the dynamic generation script. It will use the env.d
to have haproxy hosts. The first host from the
generated inventory will be considered as master,
while the others are slaves. The keepalived role
will only run if more than haproxy host is found
in the inventory. This behaviour can be changed
and keepalived can be disabled by the variable:
haproxy_use_keepalived.

The implemented variables are the following:
* haproxy_keepalived_(ext|int)ernal_vip_cidr
* haproxy_keepalived_(ext|int)ernal_interface
* haproxy_keepalived_(ext|int)ernal_virtual_router_id
* haproxy_keepalived_priority_backup
* haproxy_keepalived_priority_master
* haproxy_keepalived_vars_file

In these variables, only the following variables
are necessary: keepalived_(ext|int)ernal_vip_cidr
However, it's recommended to also configure the
keepalived_(ext|int)ernal_interface
(to know which interface the vips can bind on)

Closes-Bug: 1414397

This patch adds a configuration option for creating/updating/deleting
cluster nodes. When creating a cluster, we may need to control the

have an opportunity to attach a policy to the cluster to control the
